Get started with Ocsight, the OpenCode ecosystem observability platform

# Welcome to Ocsight

Ocsight is a powerful observability platform designed specifically for the OpenCode ecosystem. It provides comprehensive monitoring, logging, and analytics capabilities to help you understand and optimize your OpenCode workflows.

## What is Ocsight?

Ocsight gives you deep insights into your OpenCode usage with:

- **Real-time Monitoring**: Track agent performance, tool usage, and response times
- **Advanced Analytics**: Understand patterns in your development workflows
- **Smart Alerts**: Get notified about important events and anomalies
- **Beautiful Dashboards**: Visualize your data with clean, brutalist interfaces

## Quick Start

Get up and running in minutes:

```bash
# Install via curl
curl -fsSL https://get.ocsight.dev | sh

# Or via npm
npm install -g ocsight

# Or via bun
bun install -g ocsight

# Or via brew
brew install ocsight
```

- [Installation Guide](/docs/getting-started) - Complete setup instructions
- [CLI Overview](../cli/index.md) - Learn the command-line interface
- [Configuration](/docs/guides/usage#configuration) - Customize your setup
- [MCP Integration](/docs/mcp/) - Connect with Model Context Protocol

- Check our [Documentation](../) for detailed guides
- Join our community discussions
- Report issues on GitHub

Explore the ocsight CLI surface area and how to drive it efficiently.

# ocsight CLI

The `ocsight` CLI ships with every installation and exposes the full observability surface from your terminal. Commands are deterministic, documented, and designed for both human operators and automation pipelines.

## Installation recap

Use any installer from the landing page:

```bash
# npm
npm install -g ocsight

# bun
bun install -g ocsight

# homebrew
brew install killerkidbo/tap/ocsight
```

Verify the binary is available:

```bash
ocsight --version
```

## Command map

| Command | Purpose | Common flags |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `ocsight analyze` | Aggregate sessions, tokens, providers, and spend. | `--days`, `--start`, `--end`, `--provider`, `--project` |
| `ocsight stats` | Deep dive into tool performance and execution timings. | `--days`, `--tools`, `--provider` |
| `ocsight export` | Generate CSV, JSON, or Markdown reports for sharing. | `--format`, `--output`, `--days`, `--project` |
| `ocsight mcp` | Run the Model Context Protocol server for agent integrations. | `--port`, `--config` |

Dive into each command for exhaustive options:

- [analyze](/docs/cli/commands/analyze)
- [stats](/docs/cli/commands/stats)
- [export](/docs/cli/commands/export)
- [mcp](/docs/cli/commands/mcp)

## Global options

All commands support the following flags:

```bash
--log-level <trace|debug|info|warn|error>
--config <path-to-config>
--json     # structured JSON output
--no-color # remove ANSI color codes
```

## Exit codes

ocsight returns POSIX-friendly exit codes:

| Code | Meaning |
| --- | --- |
| `0` | Command completed successfully |
| `1` | Operational failure (network, filesystem, validation) |
| `2` | Invalid command usage |
| `130` | Interrupted by the user |

# CLI Simulator Demo

This page demonstrates the interactive CLI simulator component that can be embedded in documentation to provide hands-on examples.

## What is the CLI Simulator?

The CLI Simulator is an interactive component that allows users to experience command-line interactions directly within the documentation. It provides a realistic terminal experience with:

- **Real-time command execution** - See commands run as you type
- **Syntax highlighting** - Proper color coding for commands and output
- **Copy functionality** - Easy copying of commands to clipboard
- **Responsive design** - Works on all device sizes

import CLISimulator from '../../../components/CLISimulator.astro'

### Command History

<CLISimulator

How to use ocsight for code analysis

# Usage

Learn how to use ocsight to analyze your codebase effectively.

## Basic Analysis

Analyze your current directory:

```bash
ocsight analyze .
```

Analyze a specific directory:

```bash
ocsight analyze /path/to/project
```

## Export Results

Export analysis to JSON:

```bash
ocsight export --format json --output analysis.json
```

Export to CSV:

```bash
ocsight export --format csv --output analysis.csv
```

## View Statistics

Get quick statistics:

```bash
ocsight stats
```

## Advanced Options

### Filtering by File Type

Analyze only TypeScript files:

```bash
ocsight analyze --include "*.ts,*.tsx" .
```

### Excluding Directories

Skip node_modules and build directories:

```bash
ocsight analyze --exclude "node_modules/**,dist/**,build/**" .
```

### Output Formats

Multiple output formats supported:

```bash
ocsight analyze --format json .
ocsight analyze --format csv .
ocsight analyze --format table .
```

## Configuration

Create a `.ocsightrc` file for project-specific settings:

```json
{
  "include": ["src/**/*", "lib/**/*"],
  "exclude": ["node_modules/**", "dist/**"],
  "format": "json",
  "output": "analysis.json"
}
```
Complete installation and setup guide for Ocsight

# Getting Started with Ocsight

This guide will help you install and configure Ocsight on your system.

## Prerequisites

Before installing Ocsight, ensure you have:

- **Node.js**: Version 18 or higher
- **Operating System**: macOS, Linux, or Windows (WSL2)
- **Terminal**: Access to command line
- **OpenCode Account**: For cloud features (optional)

## Installation

Choose your preferred installation method:

### Method 1: Install Script (Recommended)

```bash
curl -fsSL https://get.ocsight.dev | sh
```

This script will:
- Detect your operating system
- Download the latest version
- Install to the appropriate location
- Add to your PATH

### Method 2: Package Managers

#### npm
```bash
npm install -g ocsight
```

#### bun
```bash
bun install -g ocsight
```

#### Homebrew (macOS)
```bash
brew install ocsight
```

### Method 3: Manual Installation

1. Download the latest release from [GitHub](https://github.com/opencode-ai/ocsight/releases)
2. Extract the archive
3. Move the binary to your PATH:
   ```bash
   # macOS/Linux
   sudo mv ocsight /usr/local/bin/
   
   # Windows
   move ocsight.exe C:\Program Files\ocsight\
   ```

## Verification

Verify your installation:

```bash
ocsight --version
```

You should see the version number printed.

## Initial Setup

### 1. Initialize Configuration

```bash
ocsight init
```

This creates a configuration file at `~/.ocsight/config.toml`.

### 2. Authentication (Optional)

For cloud features, authenticate with your OpenCode account:

```bash
ocsight auth login
```

### 3. Test Your Setup

```bash
ocsight status
```

This will show your current system status and connectivity.

## Configuration

Ocsight uses a TOML configuration file. Here's a basic setup:

```toml
# ~/.ocsight/config.toml
[general]
log_level = "info"
data_dir = "~/.ocsight/data"

[monitoring]
enabled = true
interval = "30s"

[alerts]
enabled = true
email = "your-email@example.com"

[cloud]
enabled = false
# api_key = "your-api-key"
```

## Next Steps

- [CLI Overview](/docs/cli/) - Learn all available commands
- [Configuration](/docs/guides/usage#configuration) - Advanced configuration options
- [MCP Integration](/docs/mcp/) - Connect with Model Context Protocol

## Troubleshooting

### Installation Issues

**Permission Denied:**
```bash
# Try with sudo (Linux/macOS)
sudo curl -fsSL https://get.ocsight.dev | sh

# Or install to user directory
curl -fsSL https://get.ocsight.dev | sh -s -- --prefix ~/.local
```

**PATH Issues:**
Add Ocsight to your PATH manually:
```bash
# Add to your shell profile (~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, etc.)
export PATH="$PATH:/path/to/ocsight"
```

### Runtime Issues

**Connection Errors:**
```bash
# Check network connectivity
ocsight doctor

# Reset configuration
ocsight config reset
```

**Permission Issues:**
```bash
# Fix permissions
sudo chown -R $USER:$USER ~/.ocsight
```

## Need Help?

- Check the [Documentation](/docs/) for detailed guides
- Run `ocsight help` for command-line assistance
- Report issues on [GitHub](https://github.com/opencode-ai/ocsight/issues)

Understand how ocsight is designed and how data flows through the system

# Architecture

```
        
   CLI Commands         MCP Server          Output Formats 
  (analyze, etc)       (real-time)         (JSON,CSV,MD)   
        
                                                      
          
                                          
                      
             Data Processing             
             (Core Engine)               
                      
                                          
        
                      Data Layer                             
                
             Cache          Storage        Stream      
           (SHA256)       (OpenCode)     (Async)       
                
        
                      
            
              OpenCode Data    
              ~/.local/share/  
                opencode/      
            
```

## Components

**CLI Interface**: Entry point for all commands (analyze, stats, export)

**MCP Server**: Real-time analytics server with tools:

- `list_providers`, `get_tool_usage`, `get_daily_stats`, `analyze_project`

**Data Processing Engine**: Core logic that:

- Discovers sessions and messages
- Applies caching and streaming
- Calculates statistics
- Filters by time, provider, project

**Data Layer**:

- **Cache**: File-based caching with SHA256 validation
- **Storage**: Reads from OpenCode's `~/.local/share/opencode/storage/`
- **Stream**: Async generators for memory-efficient processing

**Output Formats**: JSON, CSV, Markdown reports

## Data Flow

1. **Input**: CLI command or MCP tool request
2. **Discovery**: Scan OpenCode storage for sessions/messages
3. **Cache Check**: Validate cached data, skip unchanged files
4. **Processing**: Stream data through analysis pipeline
5. **Analysis**: Calculate statistics, apply filters
6. **Output**: Generate terminal display or export file

# mcp {#mcp}

Start the Model Context Protocol server for programmatic access to ocsight analytics.

## Usage {#usage}

```bash
ocsight mcp
```

## What is MCP? {#what-is-mcp}

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) allows AI assistants and other tools to access ocsight's analytics capabilities programmatically. When you run `ocsight mcp`, it starts a server that exposes tools for:

- Real-time usage analysis
- Cost optimization insights
- Performance metrics
- Data export capabilities

## Starting the Server {#starting-the-server}

```bash
# Start MCP server {#start-mcp-server}
ocsight mcp

# The server will listen on a local port and provide tools to connected clients {#the-server-will-listen-on-a-local-port-and-provide-tools-to-connected-clients}
```

## Available Tools {#available-tools}

### analyze_usage {#analyze_usage}
Analyze OpenCode usage data with filtering options.

**Parameters:**
- `days` (optional): Number of days to analyze
- `provider` (optional): Filter by AI provider
- `project` (optional): Filter by project name

### get_statistics {#get_statistics}
Get detailed usage statistics and cost insights.

**Parameters:**
- `days` (optional): Number of days to analyze
- `provider` (optional): Filter by AI provider

### export_data {#export_data}
Export usage data in various formats.

**Parameters:**
- `format`: Export format (csv, json, markdown)
- `days` (optional): Number of days to include
- `output` (optional): Output file path

## Integration Examples {#integration-examples}

### With AI Assistants {#with-ai-assistants}

MCP allows AI assistants to:
- Monitor your development costs in real-time
- Provide optimization recommendations
- Generate usage reports automatically
- Alert on unusual spending patterns

### With Development Tools {#with-development-tools}

Integrate ocsight analytics into:
- CI/CD pipelines
- Project management tools
- Cost monitoring dashboards
- Performance tracking systems

## Configuration {#configuration}

The MCP server automatically discovers your OpenCode data directory. No additional configuration is required.

  • tool: Primary tool used
  • duration_ms: Session duration in milliseconds
  • session_id: Unique session identifier

Data Storage {#data-storage}

Section titled Data Storage {#data-storage}

ocsight reads data from OpenCodes standard storage locations:

  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/OpenCode/
  • Linux: ~/.config/OpenCode/
  • Windows: %APPDATA%\OpenCode\

Data is stored in SQLite databases and JSON files containing session information, messages, and metadata.
